column4: i'm using a dell miniv (with whatever ubuntu customization comes on it).  I have a program i wrote that I can successfully invoke on the command line, but if i add it as a "file" on the shortcut grid, it doesn't start.  another option is to add an "application", but I"m not sure how to get my program on there.  any ideas?  does this make sense?
: maybe add execution right to that file? e.g. : chmod +x <the_file>
ah, good idea
nope, doesn't fix it
already +x
: what program btw? can you give more info?
i wrote a GUI for some hardware we've developed.  at the command line i can invoke it and it works fine
: in what language?
no error message or anything
: maybe you need to add the "full" command to the shortcut, e.g. java -jar myprogram.jar
that's what is in there now.. /home/xitome/RSD/RSD
: what language is that program? C/Java/Ruby?
ah, got it (sorta).  need to add it as a file, then change it to an "application"
: if it's a shell script, then you'll need to add "sh" in front of it : e.g. "sh /path/to/my/program/myprogram"
it's not, it's a compiled executable
how do you make sure it's run from it's directory?
i have some xpms that are images on buttons, spash screen, etc.  they're not loading since it's running from some random directory
: depends on the source code I suppose, what language it is?
c++.  this seems like a windowing system setup to me.. like in windws you specify which directory the application lauches in
: sorry I'm not familiar with C++
http://forum.soft32.com/linux2/Gnome-Defining-Launched-Application-Working-Directory-ftopict54771.html had my solution.  needed to make a shell script to change to the local directory
: I see...
